typeface-halyardDisplay.description:
This typeface was chosen as it looks great in darkmode, even at small font sizes. 

It has limited styles which is why not all tailwind fontweights are populated. 

It also has a variable font in it's package for more sophisticated responsive design tokens.

This typeface was chosen as it looks great in darkmode, even at small font sizes. 

It has limited styles which is why not all tailwind fontweights are populated. 

It also has a variable font in it's package for more sophisticated responsive design tokens.

2xs.description: This is NOT a standard tailwind breakpoint but is important to consider for people using mobile phone web browsers.

xs.description: This is NOT a standard tailwind breakpoint but is important to consider for people using mobile phone web browsers.

sm.description:
The TABLET screen by default in tailwind.config.js 
To be condidered as the first size that is NOT mobile, and therefore may require custom styling.

lg.description: The LAPTOP screen by default in tailwind.config.js

xl.description: The DESKTOP screen by default in tailwind.config.js

2xl.description: The breakpoint used for EXTRA WIDE DESKTOP devices

rem_base.description: This token is referenced in the Tokens Studio plugin setting as the value of 1 rem unit as a personal preference. If you don't use this setting you may remove this token.

NOTES_on_TW-DIMENSIONS.description:
To keep the number of tokens minimal, the FIXED DIMENSION tokens can be applied to padding, margin, space-betweem gap, width and hight element properties. Looking at TW Docs, the code for these classes differs, but the number and the valiue are consistent. 

Ex: space-x-1 is 0.25rem space between on the x-axis which is the same as the fixed.1 token. 

py-1 is padding top and bottom at 0.25rem which is the same as the fixed.1 token. 

So it makes sense to apply these tokens to these values, and let developers worry about the code classes. They will see the dimension token name applied via variables which should speed up the development process.

NOTES_on_OUTLINE-OFFSET.description:
The space between the element and the outline. 

In Figma, it is applied as a stroke width via border token to a frame that mimics the outline. The frame has  a border and no fill, then is absolutely positioned on the parent element with constraints set TOP + BOTTOM, RIGHT + LEFT to allow for autolayout to control outline. 

TW DOCS -> https://tailwindcss.com/docs/outline-offset

NOTES_on_OUTLINE-WIDTH.description:
The width of the outline. 

In Figma, it is applied as a stroke width via border token to a frame that mimics the outline. The frame has  a border and no fill, then is absolutely positioned on the parent element with constraints set TOP + BOTTOM, RIGHT + LEFT to allow for autolayout to control outline. 

Border tokens are composite tokens and will need to be transofrmed to see their values in code. 

TW DOCS -> https://tailwindcss.com/docs/outline-width

NOTES_on_BORDER-WIDTH.value: Applied to any element with a border
NOTES_on_BORDER-WIDTH.description:
The width of the border. In Figma, it is applied as a stroke width via border token to a frame. As border tokens are composite, they will need to be transformed to see all values in code. 

TW DOCS -> https://tailwindcss.com/docs/border-width

normal-case.description: Selects the "As typed" case option in Figma's typography design properties. In Tailwind CSS they note "The normal-case utility can be used to preserve the original casing  typically to reset capitalization at different breakpoints."

capitalize.description: Selects the "Title case" case option in Figma's typography design properties which doesn't behave as epected but rather capitalizes the first letter of every word.

numeric-values.description:
Figma has a written version of the weight, which is combined with some additional styling properties, like italics. This doesn't match the way Tailwind handles font, weights. 

So the names of the tokens contain the numeric value of the property which matches the class name as best as possible. 

Tailwind docs on Font Weight followed live here https://tailwindcss.com/docs/font-weight

customizing.description: Figma has a unique way of handling weights in that it uses a written value combined with some styling properties, like italics. The written value is also different between type faces. I suggest if you want to change the typeface and weight, to create them as styles in Figma to import the individual tokens in its own set, and customize from there.

Figma has a unique way of handling font families in that it uses a written value of font weights combined with some styling properties, like italics. The written value of font weights are different between type faces. I suggest if you want to change the typeface and weight, to create them as styles in Figma to import the individual tokens in its own set, and customize from there. 

See the token set typeface-satoshi for an example.

customization.description: this token set has the default values of font sizes listed on the tailwind website. If you want to use these, you'll need to swap out the line high of choice in your typography styles by changing the reference tokens.

leading-none.description: 100% needs to be transformed as value 1 to match CSS

leading-tight.description: 125% needs to be transformed as value 1.25 to match CSS

leading-snug.description: 138% needs to be transformed as value 1.375 to match CSS

leading-normal.description: 150% needs to be transformed as value 1.5 to match CSS

leading-relaxed.description: 163% needs to be transformed as value 1.625 to match CSS

leading-loose.description: 200% needs to be transformed as value 2 to match CSS

0.description: In Tailwind CSS, the property for controlling the vertical space between paragraphs is handled by the space-y-{amount} utility class. This class allows you to quickly and easily set the space between paragraphs, with {amount} being replaced by the spacing size you want to apply.

leading-normal.description:
Calculated in a template set using the formula:

ceil(roundTo({fontSize_token}*{1.5},0) /{factor})*{factor}

where factor = 4

to ensure that the line heights, which control the size of the text containers, always land on the 4pt grid.

leading-snug.description:
Calculated in a template set using the formula:

ceil(roundTo({fontSize_token}*{1.375},0) /{factor})*{factor}

where factor = 4

to ensure that the line heights, which control the size of the text containers, always land on the 4pt grid.

font-size-pairing.value: Absolute values are calculated based on font size
font-size-pairing.description: This means if you change the font size, you'll want to recalculate the absolute values, or switch to relative line hights, which exist in the default token set.

customization.description:
The font sizes in this token set differ from the Tailwind standard values. 

The tailwind docs state "You can configure your own custom set of font size utilities using the theme.fontSize section of your tailwind.config.js file." - https://tailwindcss.com/docs/font-size

rem-scale.value: 1.2 multiplier and rounded to factor of 4
rem-scale.description:
These font sizes were calculated using a base of 1rem = 16px, sizing scale of 1.2 then rounded to the nearest factor of 4 to ensure all sizes sit on the 4px grid.

These tokens have a prefix of "rem-scale" added to them for easy identification. 

You can swap the font sizes to the standard values if you want, which are also included without this prefix.

typography.value: All styles are using the sans font-family tokens

tailwind.value: how to override the default spacing scale
tailwind.description:
As described in the theme documentation, if youd like to override the default spacing scale, you can do so using the theme.spacing section of your tailwind.config.js file

TW docs -> https://tailwindcss.com/docs/customizing-spacing
